headline: ‘He forgot to Photoshop the hands’: Did this GOP candidate insert himself into a pic of Black soldiers?
author: Claire Goforth
sentences:
“His claim is BS.”
Today’s top stories
‘Little boys are so annoying’: Hooters server says teens asked for Michelob Ultra, left her a middle finger drawing as a tip
‘Tipping culture is out of control’: Worker shows stacks of DoorDash orders for customers who allegedly didn’t tip, sparking debate

https://twitter.com/NotHoodlum/status/1511580113049206793?s=20&t=kyVBBEqeq7YrlWkiFZXYIw
https://twitter.com/davisbrian111/status/1511533876497244164?s=20&t=MalWNlsEuRvYqFLdiedHXA
His campaign told a Politico reporter that a darkening filter caused the difference in the colors of the soldiers’ hands and face and provided what they say is the original image.

In it, Mandel stands in the center flanked by the other men as he says in a voiceover that he fought “alongside Marines of every color.”
Observers swiftly honed in on the photo, specifically Mandel’s hands, which appear far darker than his face.

Did Josh Mandel forget to photoshop his hands when he put this photo in his new ad pic.twitter.com/fsnO7O7j7I
— Brett Meiselas (@BMeiselas)
Twitter users also said that Mandel’s hands are much lighter in other photos.
“To ‘prove’ he isn’t racist—Ohio U.S. Senate candidate @JoshMandelOhio put a photo of himself standing with black soldiers in his latest campaign ad,” Twitter user @notcapnamerica wrote.
First Mandel got into a Twitter spat with Martin Luther King Jr.’s daughter, who took umbrage with him invoking her father’s legacy in the pro-gun, anti-critical race theory ad.

“Why he felt the need for a ‘darkening filter’ … is a mystery,” opined @camorris
“So weird that the darkening filter had no effect on his face,” wrote another.

“Problem is he forgot to photoshop the hands that clearly show he put his face on the body of a Black soldier.”
Tweets making fun of Mandel piled up.
“I’ve worked in tech for over 10 years, including working with Photoshop and multiple video editing applications,” wrote @LadyJayPersists.
The Daily Dot’s art director, Jason Reed, reviewed the photo and found the filter explanation by the campaign to be plausible.
Josh Mandel, a Republican candidate for United States Senate in Ohio, is in the hot seat over his latest campaign ad.
You folks asked if Josh Mandel’s campaign photoshopped his head onto a Black man, and I looked for answers.

pic.twitter.com/7kz5nYseje
— Natalie Allison (@natalie_allison)
The image appears 10 seconds into the ad.
Now he’s being accused of photoshopping himself into a photo of several soldiers who appear to be Black.
This led many to conclude that Mandel photoshopped his head onto a Black soldier’s body.
His campaign blames a darkening filter and released what it says is the original photo.
“The original photo isn’t great, and the filter likely did a disservice,” he added.
“Look at the difference in the color of his hands from two photos in his video!!!
Some pointed out that Mandel is the only one with a name badge on his uniform.
Rather than quell the chatter, this explanation led to further questions.
Several tweets accusing Mandel of photoshop shenanigans went viral.
The other soldiers’ hands also appear darker than their faces.
It appears a darkening filter was used on the ad.
Here’s the original photo for comparison.
They did not, the campaign says.
Again, the campaign denies it.
Some still aren’t convinced.
The internet has questions.
Many aren’t convinced.
The campaign says no.
(Mandel is Jewish.)
!” wrote one.
